label: thm-geometry-guarantees-variance
title: Geometric Structure Guarantees Measurement Variance
nl_statement: There exists a positional variance threshold \(R^2_{\mathrm{var}} > 0\) and a positive \(\varepsilon\)-dependent constant \(\kappa_{\text{meas}}(\epsilon) > 0\) such that for any swarm with \(k \geq 2\) alive walkers, if the internal positional variance satisfies \(\mathrm{Var}(x) \ge R^2_{\mathrm{var}}\), then the expected empirical variance of the raw distance-to-companion measurements is \(\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{Var}(d)] \ge \kappa_{\text{meas}}(\epsilon) > 0\).

conclusion.text: The expected empirical variance of the raw distance-to-companion measurements is uniformly bounded below.

variables.name: number of alive walkers
variables.description: Number of alive walkers in the swarm

implicit_assumptions.text: Swarm positions are in a Euclidean or metric space allowing variance computation.
The pairing operator produces valid companion pairings for distance measurements.

label: thm-derivation-of-stability-condition
title: Derivation of the Stability Condition for Intelligent Adaptation
nl_statement: Under the foundational axioms including non-deceptive landscapes and sufficient swarm positional variance, the algorithm's targeting mechanism is intelligent—meaning high-error walkers have systematically lower expected fitness than low-error walkers—if and only if the parameters satisfy the stability condition β ln(1 + κ_{mean,d'}(ε)/(g_{A,max} + η)) > α ln(1 + κ_{mean,r'}/η).

hypotheses.text: The system satisfies the foundational axioms, including the Axiom of Non-Deceptive Landscapes (EG-7).
Swarm k has sufficiently large internal positional variance.

conclusion.text: The algorithm's targeting mechanism is intelligent (expected fitness of high-error walker systematically lower than low-error walker) if and only if the parameters (α, β, ε, etc.) satisfy the Stability Condition.

variables.name: epsilon
variables.description: Error threshold parameter in the stability condition.

variables.name: kappa_mean_d_prime
variables.description: Mean curvature or density factor for deviated positions depending on epsilon.

variables.name: g_A_max
variables.description: Maximum gradient of the attraction function.

variables.name: kappa_mean_r_prime
variables.description: Mean curvature or density factor for reference positions.

implicit_assumptions.text: The system is a well-posed Fragile Gas system with statistical analysis applicable to population fitness.
Parameters α, β, ε are positive real numbers ensuring logarithmic terms are defined.

steps.text: Proof to be derived statistically by comparing expected fitness of high-error vs. low-error populations under axioms.

label: thm-stability-condition-final-corrected
title: The Corrected Stability Condition for Intelligent Adaptation
nl_statement: For a swarm k in a high-error state, the algorithm's targeting mechanism is intelligent (i.e., \mathbb{E}[\ln(V_{\text{fit}})|H_k] < \mathbb{E}[\ln(V_{\text{fit}})|L_k]) if and only if the system parameters satisfy \beta \ln\left(1 + \frac{\kappa_{d', \text{mean}}}{g_{A,\max}+\eta}\right) > \alpha \ln\left(1 + \frac{\kappa_{\mathrm{rescaled}}(L_{R} \cdot D_{\mathrm{valid}})}{\eta}\right).

hypotheses.text: A swarm k is in a high-error state.
The algorithm's targeting mechanism is intelligent, i.e., \mathbb{E}[\ln(V_{\text{fit}})|H_k] < \mathbb{E}[\ln(V_{\text{fit}})|L_k].

conclusion.text: The system parameters satisfy the Corrected Stability Condition: \beta \ln\left(1 + \frac{\kappa_{d', \text{mean}}}{g_{A,\max}+\eta}\right) > \alpha \ln\left(1 + \frac{\kappa_{\mathrm{rescaled}}(L_{R} \cdot D_{\mathrm{valid}})}{\eta}\right).

label: thm-unfit-high-error-overlap-fraction
title: N-Uniform Lower Bound on the Unfit-High-Error Overlap Fraction
nl_statement: For a swarm state satisfying \(V_{\mathrm{struct}} > R^2_{\mathrm{spread}}\), with \(U_k\) the unfit set and \(H_k(\epsilon)\) the high-error set, if the Stability Condition holds, then the fraction of alive walkers in their intersection \(I_{UH} = U_k \cap H_k(\epsilon)\) is bounded below by a positive N-uniform constant: \(\frac{|I_{UH}|}{k} \ge f_{UH}(\epsilon) > 0\).

label: thm-positional-variance-contraction
title: Positional Variance Contraction Under Cloning
nl_statement: Under the foundational axioms of Chapter 4, there exist constants κ_x > 0, C_x < ∞, and structural error threshold R²_spread > 0, all independent of N, such that for any pair of swarms (S_1, S_2), the expected positional variance after cloning contracts: E_clone[V_Var,x(S'_1, S'_2) | S_1, S_2] ≤ (1 - κ_x) V_Var,x(S_1, S_2) + C_x. Moreover, if V_Var,x(S_1, S_2) > \tilde{C}_x for sufficiently large \tilde{C}_x, then E_clone[Δ V_Var,x] < 0, where Δ V_Var,x = V_Var,x(S'_1, S'_2) - V_Var,x(S_1, S_2).

equations.latex: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[V_{\text{Var},x}(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2] \leq (1 - \kappa_x) V_{\text{Var},x}(S_1, S_2) + C_x

hypotheses.text: Under the foundational axioms (Chapter 4)
There exist constants κ_x > 0, C_x < ∞, and R²_spread > 0, all independent of N
For any pair of swarms (S_1, S_2)
When V_Var,x(S_1, S_2) > 	ilde{C}_x for sufficiently large 	ilde{C}_x

conclusion.text: The expected positional variance after cloning satisfies the contraction inequality, and becomes strictly negative when above the threshold

implicit_assumptions.text: Constants are independent of swarm size N
Cloning process is stochastic, allowing for expectation
Swarms S_1 and S_2 are valid under foundational axioms

label: thm-boundary-potential-contraction
title: Boundary Potential Contraction Under Cloning
nl_statement: Under the foundational axioms including the Safe Harbor Axiom, there exist constants κ_b > 0 and C_b < ∞ independent of N such that for any pair of swarms (S_1, S_2), the expected boundary potential after cloning is at most (1 - κ_b) times the original plus C_b. Furthermore, when W_b(S_1, S_2) > \tilde{C}_b for sufficiently large \tilde{C}_b, the expected change in boundary potential is negative.

equations.latex: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[W_b(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2] \leq (1 - \kappa_b) W_b(S_1, S_2) + C_b

hypotheses.text: Under the foundational axioms (Chapter 4) including the Safe Harbor Axiom (Axiom 4.3)
For any pair of swarms (S_1, S_2)
When W_b(S_1, S_2) > \tilde{C}_b for sufficiently large threshold \tilde{C}_b

conclusion.text: There exist constants \kappa_b > 0 and C_b < \infty, both independent of N, such that \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[W_b(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2] \leq (1 - \kappa_b) W_b(S_1, S_2) + C_b, and the contraction becomes strict with \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta W_b] < 0

nl_statement: The cloning operator Ψ_clone induces a drift on the boundary potential W_b satisfying E_clone[ΔW_b] ≤ -κ_b W_b + C_b, where κ_b = p_boundary(φ_thresh) > 0 is N-independent, C_b = O(σ_x² + N^{-1}), ensuring unconditional contraction for W_b > C_b/κ_b and strengthening near the boundary.

C_b = O(σ_x² + N^{-1}) accounts for position jitter and dead walker revival

conclusion.text: The cloning operator Ψ_clone induces the following drift on the boundary potential with unconditional contraction for W_b > C_b/κ_b and strengthening near danger via increasing κ_b with boundary proximity through φ_thresh

nl_statement: For the coupled cloning operator acting on two swarms (S₁, S₂), the expected change in the hypocoercive Wasserstein distance V_W = W_h²(μ₁, μ₂) = V_loc + V_struct satisfies E_clone[ΔV_W] ≤ C_W, where C_W < ∞ is a state-independent constant. Equivalently, E_clone[V_W(S'₁, S'₂)] ≤ V_W(S₁, S₂) + C_W.

label: thm-complete-wasserstein-drift
title: Complete Wasserstein Decomposition Drift
nl_statement: The total inter-swarm Wasserstein distance \(V_W = V_{\text{loc}} + V_{\text{struct}}\) satisfies \(\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_W] \leq C_W\) under the cloning operator, where \(C_W = C_{\text{loc}} + C_{\text{struct}}\) is a finite state-independent constant, with component bounds \(\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{loc}}] \leq C_{\text{loc}}\) and \(\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{struct}}] \leq C_{\text{struct}}\); the kinetic operator yields \(\mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_W] \leq -\kappa_W^{\text{kin}} \tau V_W + C_W^{\text{kin}} \tau\).

label: thm-complete-cloning-drift
title: Complete Drift Inequality for the Cloning Operator
nl_statement: Under foundational axioms, the cloning operator induces bounded or contracting drifts on components of the synergistic Lyapunov function, yielding overall negative drift when variance and boundary terms are sufficiently large.

equations.latex: V_{\text{total}}(S_1, S_2) = V_W(S_1, S_2) + c_V V_{\text{Var}}(S_1, S_2) + c_B W_b(S_1, S_2)
\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] \leq C_W + c_V(-\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_v + C_x) + c_B(-\kappa_b W_b + C_b)
\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] < 0 \quad \text{when } c_V V_{\text{Var},x} + c_B W_b > \frac{C_W + c_V(C_v + C_x) + c_B C_b}{\min(\kappa_x, \kappa_b)}

Individual component drifts hold as specified

conclusion.text: The cloning operator Ψ_clone induces the stated drift inequalities on the synergistic Lyapunov function V_total, with partial contraction when c_V V_Var,x + c_B W_b exceeds the threshold.

label: thm-synergistic-foster-lyapunov-preview
title: Synergistic Foster-Lyapunov Condition (Preview)
nl_statement: When the coupling constants c_V and c_B are chosen appropriately, the composed operator Ψ_total = Ψ_kin ∘ Ψ_clone satisfies a Foster-Lyapunov drift condition: E_total[V_total(S')] ≤ (1 - κ_total) V_total(S) + C_total for some κ_total > 0 and C_total < ∞, both independent of N. This implies geometric ergodicity of the Markov chain on the alive state space and exponential convergence to the quasi-stationary distribution.

conclusion.text: The composed operator Ψ_total = Ψ_kin ∘ Ψ_clone satisfies a Foster-Lyapunov drift condition: E_total[V_total(S')] ≤ (1 - κ_total) V_total(S) + C_total for some κ_total > 0 and C_total < ∞, both independent of N. This implies: 1. Geometric ergodicity of the Markov chain on the alive state space. 2. Exponential convergence to the quasi-stationary distribution.

nl_statement: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system of equations for the alive density f(t,z) and the dead mass m_d(t), with total population conservation m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1.

label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
nl_statement: Under regularity assumptions on the domain, integrator, and density, there exists a smooth compactly supported killing rate function c such that the discrete exit probability converges pointwise to c as the timestep τ approaches 0, and the expected discrete killing fraction converges to the continuous killing integral with an explicit error bound involving √τ and the L¹ norm of the density difference.

label: thm-mean-field-limit-informal
title: Mean-Field Limit (Informal Statement)
nl_statement: In the joint limit as the number of particles N approaches infinity and the timestep τ approaches 0 with τ scaling as O(N^{-α}) for α > 0, the empirical density of the N-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics converges weakly to the mean-field density f.

equations.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: The system consists of N-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics (X_i^τ(t), V_i^τ(t))_{i=1}^N with timestep τ.
The empirical density is defined as f_N^τ(t, x, v) = (1/N) ∑_{i=1}^N δ(x - X_i^τ(t), v - V_i^τ(t)).
hypotheses.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: Joint limit N → ∞, τ → 0 with τ = O(N^{-α}) for α > 0.

conclusion.text: The empirical density converges weakly to the mean-field density f.
